title: What do the lyrics to Tiny Dancer mean? - Quora

response.answer_text: If I may, I’d like to comment on one particular lyric in the song: “Jesus freaks out in the street, handing tickets out for God.” I first heard this song around 1990, when I started listening to Classic Rock radio. A year earlier, I had done a term paper in college about the Jesus Movement of the late-60s/70s (the “Jesus freaks” or Jesus People). They were hippies who became born-again Christians but continued dressing and speaking like members of the counterculture. In my research I learned that there was a particular group of Jesus People called the Alamo Christian Foundation, which developed eventually into a cult. Anyway, they were formed in 1969 in Hollywood, CA, and in the early days they would walk the streets of Hollywood recruiting people into their group, offering them a meal if they would come to their headquarters for a prayer meeting. So when I first heard the song “Tiny Dancer” and its reference to “Jesus freaks” in Hollywood, I thought, “Is he singing about the Alamo Christian Foundation?” I’ve never heard anyone confirm it, but the facts seem to fit that conclusion. Bernie Taupin wrote the song after his first visit to the US in 1970. The Alamo Christian Foundation had been founded only a year before and was still working the streets of Hollywood at that time. So he may very well have seen them and included them in the song! Just wanted to add that to a discussion of the lyrics because it’s rarely mentioned. I read another site online where someone suggested that the “Jesus freaks” in the song were probably Hare Krishnas, but that’s highly unlikely. Hare Krishnas were/are a very different movement which worships Krishna, not Jesus. There was a definite religious movement among hippies at the time, the adherents of which were commonly called “Jesus freaks,” so it only makes sense that Taupin was referring to them.

Well knowing the song lyrics pretty well…I would say that it has to do with women or a woman of the night (hooker/prostitute)…and her life on the streets of LA…lonely,sad, desperate for companionship,to be noticed,to be paid attention to..to be either a rock star or with a rock star…or swept off her feet by a rock star…she's living a pipe dream,an illusion of her reality and knowing her reality is nothing like her dreams or fantasies…so when she's with her “John’s" she pretends that it's the real thing that she's with a rock star… she's empty inside…and inside her head she has conversation with herself …. she's the only one who knows how she truly really feels inside about herself…she's very unhappy and alone…she feels that God can't save her or she's not worth saving..so she laughs at the hara chrishners for trying to give her pamphets about salvation..so that's what I get from the song lyrics.

The short answer: It was written by Elton and Bernie when they were living in L.A., trying to figure out of they could “break into the music business.” Maxine Feibelmann, who was Bernie Taupin's girlfriend when he wrote the song and who became his first wife in 1971. She traveled with the band on their early tours, often sewing together the costumes and fixing their clothes. Plus, on the Madman Across The Water album, it says, "With love to Maxine" under the credits for this song. Elton John even said at one point that Bernie wrote it about his girlfriend. But in the larger sense, it was about LA, the end of the sixties, the co opting of the Sunset Strip by Big Money.
Don't know the deeper meanings of the words but by all accounts it's about Bernie Taupin’s wife at the time.
